Sure, one example of where partial differential equations are used in engineering is in the study of fluid dynamics. Fluid dynamics is concerned with the behavior of fluids (such as air or water) in motion and how they interact with their environment. 

For example, in fluid dynamics, engineers may need to study the flow of water through a pipe, the motion of air over the wing of an airplane, or the behavior of molten metal in a manufacturing process. To model these types of systems, engineers use partial differential equations that describe the relationships between various physical quantities, such as pressure, velocity, and temperature, as well as the geometry of the system.

By solving these partial differential equations, engineers can gain insights into the behavior of fluid systems and make predictions about how they will perform under different conditions. This information can be used to design more efficient or effective systems, such as aircraft wings that generate more lift, or manufacturing processes that produce higher-quality products.
